data.source: Quantitative online survey via an ISO-certified online access panel
data.wave_or_subset: Single wave collected March 19–23, 2020; adults (18+) in Germany who, as far as they are aware, are not infected with COVID-19; post-cleaning sample after excluding completions under 7 minutes
data.sample_size: N=1242 after data cleansing (1300 completed before cleaning)
data.notes: All questions were mandatory. Sample is online-representative with respect to gender, age, and federal state. Age range limited to 18–74 due to panel provider. Data cleansing removed respondents with completion time <7 minutes. Items on behavior partly sourced from Teufel (2020). Cronbach’s alpha for coping scales: problem-focused α=.80; emotion-focused α=.79.

method.description: An online, ISO-panel-based survey measured Germans’ risk perceptions, fears, coping strategies (problem-focused and emotion-focused), related behaviors, trust in institutions, and emergency food preparedness during March 19–23, 2020. Instruments drew on the psychometric paradigm (Slovic) and the Ways of Coping framework (Folkman & Lazarus; German version). Descriptive statistics, group comparisons (e.g., gender, age), and correlations were reported; reliability of coping scales was assessed with Cronbach’s alpha.
steps: Design questionnaire covering risk perception (cognitive and affective), coping strategies, behaviors, trust, and emergency food preparedness, using items from the psychometric paradigm and the German Ways of Coping Scale; include behavior items from Teufel (2020).
Program the survey with the ISO-certified panel provider; recruit adults (18+) in Germany via the access panel.
Field the survey March 19–23, 2020; require all questions to be answered.
Exclude respondents with completion time under 7 minutes; retain N=1242.
Verify online representativeness by gender, age, and federal state.
Compute descriptive statistics (means, SDs, percentages) for all items.
Construct problem-focused and emotion-focused coping scales; assess internal consistency (Cronbach’s alpha).
Conduct group comparisons by gender and age; report significant differences and correlations (e.g., Pearson r for age vs. coping).
Summarize findings regarding risk perception, coping styles, behaviors, institutional trust, and food preparedness.
method.models: Descriptive statistics; group comparisons (e.g., tests of mean/percentage differences with p-values reported); Pearson correlation analyses; scale reliability assessment (Cronbach’s alpha).
method.outcome_variable: Multiple: perceived likelihood of infection (self, family/friends, general), fear and worry about COVID-19, problem-focused and emotion-focused coping scale scores, specific protective behaviors (e.g., handwashing, avoiding public places/transport), trust in institutions, and days/extent of emergency food supplies.
method.independent_variables: Age, gender, federal state; descriptive urban/rural residence.

results.summary: Respondents perceived higher infection risk for family/friends than for themselves; older adults perceived lower infection likelihood than younger adults. Women reported greater worry and fear than men. COVID-19 was seen as a global disaster but also as controllable and reducible. Coping was predominantly problem-focused, with high adherence to expert advice and careful behavior. Many engaged in protective behaviors (hand hygiene, avoiding public places/transport). Trust was highest in medical institutions and experts, followed by companies and politics. About half had food supplies for 10–11 days, and 41.9% reported buying more food than usual, motivated by reduced shopping frequency and quarantine preparedness.
